title: 108_s929
content: The Act may be cited as the "Max Cleland Over-the-Road Bus Security and Safety Act of 2003". It provides emergency security assistance for over-the-road buses. The "Max Cleland Over-the-Road Bus Security and Safety Act of 2003" establishes a program for grants to improve security for private over-the-road bus operators, including constructing secure facilities, protecting drivers, upgrading equipment for passenger information, and training employees in security procedures. The Act establishes grants for over-the-road bus security improvements, including security procedures, hiring/training officers, installing surveillance equipment, employee background checks, emergency communication systems, and passenger screening programs. Grants can also reimburse operators for security-related costs incurred since September 11, 2001. The Act establishes grants for over-the-road bus security improvements, with a 90 percent Federal share of costs. The Secretary must consider private operators who have enhanced security measures since September 11, 2001. Grants are subject to terms and conditions outlined in the Transportation Equity Act. The Act requires private operators of over-the-road buses to submit a security improvement plan for approval before receiving a grant. Applicants must coordinate security improvements with terminal owners if the improvements are proposed for a terminal not owned by the applicant. Additionally, the Act defines over-the-road bus. The Act defines an over-the-road bus as a bus with an elevated passenger deck over a baggage compartment. Additionally, private operators must submit a security improvement plan for approval before receiving a grant. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a preliminary report to specific committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will assess the over-the-road bus security grant program, actions taken to address security issues, and the need for additional safety measures or legislation. The Secretary of Homeland Security must assess the need for additional legislation to enhance security for Americans traveling on over-the-road buses, evaluate the economic impact of security upgrades on the industry, research on bus security technologies, and industry best practices. Consultation with industry, labor, and other groups is required for this assessment. The curr_chunk involves road bus management, labor representatives, public safety, law enforcement officials, and the National Academy of Sciences. The Act authorizes funding of $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2003 and $99,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 for security improvements to over-the-road bus operations.
